title: Software Engineer
skills: Designed and built complex data systems and data driven tools for visualization and analysis workloads in on-premises, cloud, and hybrid environments.

Architected, built, and maintained end-to-end ETL pipelines collecting experimental data from lab equipment and field devices in short term and multi year experiments for both streaming and continuous batch workloads.
Technical leader and mentor to a team of developers for the DOE Energy Materials Network (EMN) data hubs, and provided software engineer leadership to other developers across the lab.
Developed, deployed, and maintained well architected AWS cloud native workloads, hybrid workloads, and successfully migrated on-premises workloads to cloud.
Worked closely with researchers to define requirements for scientific software engineering on database schema design, APIs, analytic tool use cases, and web based visualizations.
Integrated cloud workloads with on-premises services, working with and across several departments and groups at the lab to achieve project milestones.
Developed several full stack web applications and APIs, leveraging modern web technologies and frameworks.

Maintained healthy relationships with a diverse group of scientist, engineers, and professionals by working well with others, providing constructive feedback, and inviting feedback on my performance from others.

business: Department of Energy Office of Science
title: Science Undergraduate Laboratory Intern
skills: Developed a cost-benefit model for data center demand response events.
Professional development—presented results, and technical writing. Best poster in category award.
Contributed to Ruby on Rails web projects.
